title: I just opened a Chase bank account and the bank took all my money because of an unpaid credit card debt.
question: I just opened a bank account and I deposited all my paycheck. The next day, all the funds were gone. I called the bank and they explained that I had an open unpaid debt (credit card) with another bank WAMU and they had recently acquired that bank. It took me a while to figure out which credit card I defaulted because it happened years ago.But they left not one penny in my account- literally. I have rent to pay and need food for my family and gas money. We already live paycheck to paycheck and now I don't know what to do. Is it legal what they are doing? I thought they had to go to court to get a wage garnishment. Please save the negative comments- I know I defaulted on a credit card, that I should have paid.
answers:
The "banker's lien" or bank setoff is permitted for situations where the depositor has incurred charges or fees related to the deposit account. Here, the bank has seized the funds on deposit to pay a credit card debt, for which the depositor did not authorize the payment from the deposit account. This would appear to be in violation of the Truth In Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. Sec. 1666h(a). Such claim must be filed in court within one year of the illegal act or the statute of limitation will bar that claim. To have properly taken the funds would require a judgment against you, and you did not indicate whether or not the bank or a debt collector had a levy on it from an unpaid judgment on the credit card debt.

Also, California has statutory protections for the customer when such setoff occurs, giving you the right to claim the funds are exempt or dispute the amount owed. Finally, if this was a Providian debt, it may be time barred by expiration of the statute of limitations, unless there is a judgment against you that was filed some time ago. If you need assistance with this, please contact me through my Avvo profile.

You should contact a local attorney who practices bankruptcy. i find it difficult to believe that having acquired the debt the bank was able to setoff the debt without a judgment since they were not the original lender.

Very often banks have a right of setoff built into their account agreements that allows them to take money from Account B because you haven't paid them on Account A. And it's true that an unpaid credit card from a bank that is acquired by your bank could trigger that right.

But it's also true that banks SELL defaulted credit card accounts for pennies on the dollar to junk debt buyers. And if the card you defaulted on was from Providian (WAMU bought Providian, and was subsequently acquired by Chase), the "debt" may have long ago been sold to Credigy or some other Junk Debt Buyer, which would mean, perhaps that Chase is improperly exercising the setoff. The banks can't eat their cake and have it too--if they sell the account, they can't continue to collect on it by using setoff.

I would contact a NACA.NET attorney and see if a little investigation doesn't get you your money back.
